awd_abstract_narration:
This award establishes the Dallas-Fort Worth Federal Statistical Research Data Center.  This Center joins the national network of over two dozen Federal Statistical Research Data Centers (FSRDCs). These Centers make important data gathered by federal statistical agencies available to leading researchers throughout the United States. The Dallas-Fort Worth FSRDC will be available to members of the sponsoring research consortium: the University of Texas at Dallas, the University of Texas at Arlington, the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, the University of Texas Southwest Medical Center, Southern Methodist University, Texas Tech University, the University of North Texas, Texas Christian University, and the Dallas-Fort Worth Hospital Council Foundation. Research projects at this FSRDC include work in engineering, economics, urban planning, sociology, health, and demography. The Center will encourage greater use of federal statistical data among faculty, researchers, and graduate students in this region.  In addition, the Center will make valuable new data on health outcomes collected by Dallas hospitals available to researchers through the FSRDC network nationwide. The research made possible by this FSRDC will improve the economic competitiveness of the US and regional economies by helping policymakers at all levels understand how government decisions affect market outcomes.

Each FSRDC is a secure facility that provides leading researchers with authorized access to restricted-use data from federal statistical agencies. As a result, qualified researchers can conduct projects that are important for both science and policy while protecting respondent confidentiality. The research conducted at this FSRDC will improve statistical efforts by the federal government (including Census and other statistical agencies that make data available through FSRDCs).  The projects will utilize datasets supported by the Bureau of the Census, the National Center for Health Statistics, the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, the Bureau of Justice Statistics, the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and the Department of Agriculture.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to establish, maintain and move forward with, the Dallas-Fort Worth Federal Statistical Research Data Center (DFWRDC), which is a partnership between the U.S. Census Bureau and The University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) and a Consortium that includes the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas (FRB Dallas), where the Center is located, along with The University of Texas at Arlington, Southern Methodist University, The University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas, Texas Christian University (through 2022), Texas Tech University, Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center (through 2022), The University of North Texas, The University of Oklahoma (from 2022), and the Dallas-Fort Worth Hospital Council Foundation. The NSF award formally established the DFWRDC, and provided seed money, to allow it to be part of the system of national Federal Statistical Research Data Centers (FSRDCs).

The DFWRDC (https://dfwrdc.org/) provides access to restricted-use micro data at the individual and firm level for researchers across the social, behavioral, and health sciences, as well as other disciplines.  Most researchers in these areas typically use public-use data that must limit the detail they have due to confidentiality. For example, the full range of a variable may be limited, or the state or city where a firm is located may not be provided, to protect a firm or individual from potentially being identified. Restricted-access data permits a more detailed set of variables for the researcher, while protecting confidentiality through the protocols established in the Research Data Center. 

Research at the DFWRDC currently includes topics such as firm dynamics, income inequality, health disparities across geographic regions, race, and gender, domestic violence and substance use, food insecurity, immigration, and government procurement processes. Currently, most researchers are using data provided by the U.S. Census Bureau, the National Center for Health Statistics, and the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. We anticipate future use of other available data sources such as those from the Bureau of Economic Analysis and the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The DFWRDC will have a broad impact on the infrastructure available to scholars and students, and will influence economic, social, and health policy both regionally and nationally. The Consortium community is committed to the long-term success of the DFWRDC, and views it as a vital strategic component in the mission of each institution to improving lives through research, education, and outreach.


Last Modified: 10/17/2022
Modified by: Kurt J Beron
